Split Two-Field Column

Source: R/sv.R
split_double_col.Rd

Splits a column with 2 comma-separated fields into two columns.

split_double_col(d, nms)

Arguments

d

Input tibble data.

nms

A character vector of columns to split.

Value

A modified tibble with the original columns averaged and split nicely.

Examples

x <- tibble::tibble(
  a = letters[1:11],
  b = c("0.4,0.8", paste0(round(runif(10), 2), ",", round(runif(10), 2))),
  nacol = rep(NA, 11),
  namix = sample(c(NA, "0.4,0.6"), 11, replace = TRUE)
)
(b <- gpgr:::split_double_col(x, "b"))
#> # A tibble: 11 × 1
#>    b                
#>    <chr>            
#>  1 0.6 (0.4, 0.8)   
#>  2 0.05 (0.01, 0.09)
#>  3 0.87 (0.85, 0.89)
#>  4 0.22 (0.12, 0.31)
#>  5 0.5 (0.57, 0.42) 
#>  6 0.48 (0.47, 0.48)
#>  7 0.54 (0.93, 0.16)
#>  8 0.51 (0.11, 0.91)
#>  9 0.4 (0.67, 0.12) 
#> 10 0.47 (0.46, 0.48)
#> 11 0.53 (0.42, 0.64)
(nacol <- gpgr:::split_double_col(x, "nacol"))
#> # A tibble: 11 × 1
#>    nacol
#>    <chr>
#>  1 NA   
#>  2 NA   
#>  3 NA   
#>  4 NA   
#>  5 NA   
#>  6 NA   
#>  7 NA   
#>  8 NA   
#>  9 NA   
#> 10 NA   
#> 11 NA   
(namix <- gpgr:::split_double_col(x, "namix"))
#> # A tibble: 11 × 1
#>    namix         
#>    <chr>         
#>  1 0.5 (0.4, 0.6)
#>  2 0.5 (0.4, 0.6)
#>  3 NA            
#>  4 0.5 (0.4, 0.6)
#>  5 NA            
#>  6 0.5 (0.4, 0.6)
#>  7 NA            
#>  8 0.5 (0.4, 0.6)
#>  9 NA            
#> 10 0.5 (0.4, 0.6)
#> 11 0.5 (0.4, 0.6)
